H0.text: Conserving resources is the example of a lumber company planting new trees where a forest once stood.

H1.text: Consuming resources is an example of a lumber company planting new trees where a forest once stood.

H2.text: Recycling resources is exemplified by a lumber company planting new trees where a forest once stood.

H3.text: Replacing resources is what a lumber company does when it plants new trees where a forest once stood.

A4.text: In some countries, such as Finland, many forests are managed by the wood products and pulp and paper industry, where trees are planted to replace those that have been cut, much like other crops.

A5.text: The Finnish Forest Act from 1996 requires that forest be replanted after felling.
